course.subject: ECON
course.name: Globalization: Trade, Investment and Exchange Rate
course.description: Why globalization? Is it good or bad? This course provides students with economic frameworks to analyze and understand globalization. Topics include international trade, foreign direct investment, multinationals, exchange rates, regional trade agreements, WTO, IMF and the World Bank. There are regional case studies on Asian economies, with focus on China and Hong Kong.
course.prerequisites: (ECON 2103 OR ECON 2113 OR ECON 2913 OR ECON 3113) AND (ECON 2123 OR ECON 3123)
course.exclusions: ECON 4354, ECON 4364, ECON 4374, ECON 399H, SOSC 200D, SOSC 200E

reviews.author: Kagaho
reviews.comment_content:
This course is mainly divided into 2 parts: Micro (1st half) and Macro (2nd half). For the first half, it covers topics like comparative advantage, standard trade model, internal economies of scales, FDI, tariff and quotas etc; and for the second half, it covers BOP, exchange rates, UIP etc.

Most of the topics are covered in ECON3113 and ECON 3143. A good course for ECOF students to take.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Lai is overall an excellent professor and he is very passionate about this subject. He welcomes students to ask him questions after class or during office hour.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is pretty good. I would say this course is among one of the best graded course in ECON 4XXX level.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not particularly heavy for this course. There are 6 problem sets across the semester, with 2 midterm exams and 1 final exam. One can easily finish each problem set within one hour and that serves as a great way to consolidate what you have learnt in lectures. (In fact, the problem sets won't be marked. You will be given full credit if you "seriously attempted" the questions.) Prof will also provide sample Midterm questions hence it won't take you much time for revision.

reviews.author: kkkkkkk
reviews.title: Heavy workload but grading not bad
reviews.comment_content:
The course mainly consists 2 parts. The first part focuses on several models about international trade. The models are very complicated to understand which require substantial time to find out what is going on. Math parts are not difficult but you have to understand the principles beforehand. You have to be good in micro , otherwise it takes some time for you to understand the models.
The second part focuses on foreign exchange market. This part is much easier than the first part, especially if you are good in macro. It is basically a extended part of IS-LM model which associates outputs, interest rates and exchange rates. It is much straight-forward than the first part, so in the exam.
You will find the topics quite useful in daily life, at least you understand more about what is going on in the trade wars and currency exchange markets.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Acceptable teaching but not interesting. He attempts to cover a lot of topics but he doesn't have enough to time to do so. So he rushes so fast.
He is quite approachable and always willing to answer students' question.
Overall he is not bad.
reviews.comment_grading:
He uses both relative and absolute grading. He announces the distribution of the tests each time so you could know what grade you get based on your score. You probably get a B if you get mean and A- if you are above 1 SD, which is quite good. It is not difficult to be above mean if you study hard.

Final Exam - 40%
2 Mid-term exams - 22.5% each
Assignments - 10%
Attendance and Participation - 5%
reviews.comment_workload:
6 problem sets(but he don't mark at all. Credit would be given if seriously attempt)
Attendance and participation (he takes attendance every lectures!)
2 mid-terms 1.5 hrs each (28mc+3 long questions)
1 Final exam 3 hrs (40mc + 6 long questions)
The mid-terms and exam are extremely long. You may not have enough time if you do it too slowly.
The most difficult part is to understand the materials.   Each chapters consists of 50-60 slides which just highlight the most important part of the chapter. You have to read through the textbook to get the whole picture, though it is very time-consuming.

reviews.author: ustgrad
reviews.title: SUPER CRAZY INTENSE COURSE
reviews.comment_content: The content is super heavy, covers more than 20 chapters in the textbook and has a lot of theories. There is tons of slides and pages on the text that you MUST to read to understand the materials for exams.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mediocre teaching, for elementary topics still acceptable but for difficult topic he runs through very fast so he expects you to understand 70% of it before going to class.
reviews.comment_grading: Not bad if you do all the work, he used both absolute and relative grading for my class and give us the higher grade because it was a small class.
reviews.comment_workload:
8 Problem Sets (sometimes takes more than 3 hours each), 8-10 in-class quizzes Research paper, 30min Presentation (prof will give topic and you work in team of 4) and Mid term and Final exams (CUMULATIVE) AND attendance is counted!!!

His exams are insanely long, usually not enough time to complete but good thing is everyone else feels the same way.

You need to be mentally prepared to do the work if you're taking this class!!!
